image.altText: A museum exhibit with projections on the wall and artefacts in the middle.

props.synopsis: The Pompeii exhibition at the National Museum uses immersive audiovisual elements alongside artefacts to show attendees what life may have been like.

title.children: Tragic story of Pompeii on show at national museum

image.altText: A apartment building with cars driving on a main road in the foreground.

props.synopsis: CoreLogic data for 2024 shows house prices in Canberra are the third highest in the country, behind Sydney and Brisbane, and continue to track upwards.

title.children: The ACT's priciest and cheapest suburbs, according to CoreLogic

image.altText: Bucket of brown, murky water sitting under an outdoor tap. It looks disgusting.

props.synopsis: The last upgrade of the Yass Valley's water treatment plant was in 1990, with residents dealing with ongoing issues with the quality of their water.

title.children: Water upgrades coming for region where most won't drink from the tap

image.altText: A apartment building with cars driving on a main road in the foreground.

props.synopsis: CoreLogic data for 2024 shows house prices in Canberra are the third highest in the country, behind Sydney and Brisbane, and continue to track upwards.

title.children: The ACT's priciest and cheapest suburbs, according to CoreLogic

image.altText: Victoria Bitter

props.synopsis: The National Film and Sound Archive's 10 new additions to the Sounds of Australia registry include Chains by Tina Arena, the original Doctor Who theme, and an iconic ad for Victoria Bitter beer.

title.children: 'A hard-earned thirst': VB ad among new Sounds of Australia

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann walking into court.

props.synopsis: An indictment alleging Bruce Lehrmann raped a woman in Queensland in October 2021 has been presented to the Toowoomba District Court.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann alleged rape indictments presented to court

image.altText: Two people walk down the entrance to an inland waterway with a sign reading "Area closed for primary contact".

props.synopsis: Because of elevated bacteria levels, four sites at Lake Burley Griffin are closed for swimming, along with Cotter Avenue, Kambah Pool, Pine Island and Point Hut Crossing.

title.children: Most ACT waterways closed for swimming due to elevated bacteria

image.altText: Two unidentified people sit at a desk with several boxes labelled MS-2 Step. One wears doctor's lab coat

props.synopsis: Family Planning Australia has analysed data on medical terminations across NSW, highlighting how access to abortion remains a postcode lottery.

title.children: Family Planning report reveals abortion deserts across regional NSW

image.altText: A line of buildings streching across the shoreline of Beirut.

props.synopsis: As the Syrian dictatorship teetered on the brink, some of Bashar al-Assad's closest confidantes reportedly fled over the border to Lebanon.

title.children: On Beirut's glittering waterfront, Assad's stooges may be hiding out

image.altText: People wave the flag of the Syrian rebels.

props.synopsis: The collapse of the Assad regime has fragmented Syria's territory, with several armed groups now jostling for control and international players anxious to preserve their regional interests.

title.children: Syria in a map: Who controls what now that Assad is gone?

image.altText: A man gives an interview in a room surrounded by local residents.

props.synopsis: Travis Timmerman says he spent seven months in a cell of a notorious Syrian jail, where he says he heard other inmates being tortured.

title.children: American man freed from Syrian jail, months after vanishing in Europe

image.altText: A bombed out multi-storey building surrounded by debris in Gaza.

props.synopsis: The latest bloodshed occurred just hours after the UN General Assembly called for an immediate ceasefire in the devastated territory, with Australia supporting the motion but the US and Israel opposing it.

title.children: Guards protecting aid trucks in Gaza killed by Israeli strikes

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is poised to slip on Friday after Wall Street edged lower ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting next week. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX to slip following Wall Street losses, Qantas strike could disrupt flights

image.altText: Photo of nuclear power station chimneys

props.synopsis: Internal debate over the nuclear modelling, and when Mr Dutton should release details, has been a source of tension within the Coalition for months.

title.children: Internal Coalition unease over nuclear costings as Dutton unveils modelling

image.altText: An older white man in a suit points as he speaks sternly in front of a blue background.

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden has commuted the sentences of roughly 1,500 Americans who were released from prison and placed in home confinement during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as pardoning 39 Americans convicted of nonviolent crimes.

title.children: Biden pardons 39, commutes 1,500 sentences in record act of clemency

image.altText: A cover for TIME Magazine, showing Donald Trump in a red frame

props.synopsis: The president-elect beat out fellow nominees Kamala Harris, Princess Catherine, Joe Rogan, Elon Musk, Benjamin Netanyahu, Mark Zuckerberg, Yulia Navalnaya, Claudia Sheinbaum and Jerome Powell.

title.children: Donald Trump named Time magazine's Person of the Year for 2024

image.altText: Victorian Opposition Leader John Pesutto stands at a podium with media microphones, with three colleagues standing behind him.

props.synopsis: Liberal MPs are unsure whether Victorian Opposition Leader John Pesutto's Federal Court loss spells the end of his tenure.

title.children: A humiliating courtroom defeat might not be the end of Pesutto

image.altText: A long queue of travellers at Sydney Airport.

props.synopsis: Australian airports are preparing for record-breaking passenger numbers this holiday season, with millions taking to the skies.

title.children: Airports brace for record-breaking passenger numbers

image.altText: Helicopter view of a car on fire in bushland.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian father says he now accepts police played no role in the death of his fugitive son in 2022 — with an inquest hearing the theory originated with the operator of an amateur Facebook news page.

title.children: Father tells inquest he accepts police had no involvement in son's death

image.altText: A man in a suit at a Christmas party holding a glass of champagne and Santa hat while clutching his chest.

props.synopsis: It's the season for parties and celebrating the end of another year, but having a few too many drinks can come with downsides. Some hangover symptoms might even be a sign of a serious heart condition.

title.children: Racing heart after a big night out? You might have more than a hangover

image.altText: A striking close up illustration of a black woman in furs.

props.synopsis: While Neanderthals and modern humans lived together in Europe for only a relatively short time, two separate studies found inter-species breeding took place from around 50,000 years ago.

title.children: Oldest modern human genomes reveal when our ancestors and Neanderthals interbred

image.altText: A man with grey dreadlocks cuddles a small white dog smiling with love

props.synopsis: At the Colac Salvos, a project to repair and re-use old tents is bringing shelter to those who are often the hardest to help — the growing population of homeless men.

title.children: Musty old tents helping homeless men shelter from the harsh weather

image.altText: Man standing outside an outdoor pod.

props.synopsis: Outdoor pods have grown in popularity but one business has been targeting dissatisfied customers who leave negative reviews online — and the man behind the business has a history with several state regulators.

title.children: 'You're going to out me as a paedophile?' Customer threatened after leaving negative online review

image.altText: Spirit of Tasmania new ferry funnel lifted by cranes into place.

props.synopsis: The inclusion of Apple and a number of other international corporations as "local content" suppliers for Tasmania's new Spirit of Tasmania ferries has been blasted by the Opposition, with the government saying "there are things local businesses cannot produce but they can procure them".

title.children: Multinational corporations on the list of 'local' suppliers for new Spirit ferries

image.altText: Animals at a shelter.

props.synopsis: Animal rescue organisations are warning they are already at capacity ahead of Christmas and say a third of animal are being turned over due to cost of living stress.

title.children: Sydney animal shelters face 'perfect storm' over Christmas, RSPCA warns

image.altText: Hand dropping white and purple circles against khaki background.

props.synopsis: The charity sector's most devoted givers won't be around forever. So who will fill the gap?

title.children: Why Australian charities are finding it increasingly hard to raise money

image.altText: A composite image of Alex Jones, a PNG NRL player and a flat white being poured.

props.synopsis: Righto then smarty pants, test yourself.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Parcel poaching, coffee prices soaring and a new NRL team for PNG

props.synopsis: A man and woman were stuck on the roof of their submerged four-wheel drive for hours in remote WA after being swept away while trying to cross a river.

title.children: Stranded teachers rescued from car roof in rising outback floodwaters

image.altText: A crowd of people walking along a street carrying shopping bags on an overcast day.

props.synopsis: All states and territories experienced population growth during the past 12 months, some much faster than others.

title.children: Australia's population grows by 552,000 despite births at 17-year low

image.altText: A close up of Anthony Albanese in a suit.

props.synopsis: Unveiling eagerly-awaited plans to slug tech companies to help prop up Australian journalism, Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones insisted Labor's strategy was akin to "playing four-dimensional chess".

title.children: Can Labor win a game of '4D chess' against the tech giants?

image.altText: A PNG rugby league football player stands among a crowd of fans holding up their hands.

props.synopsis: The "soft power" aspect to this sports diplomacy initiative has never been a secret. But in the game of regional politics, Australia went in for the hard tackle.

title.children: How a shared love of NRL gave Australia an edge over China in PNG

image.altText: A computer generated image showcases an outdoor museum in an outback location.

props.synopsis: It was billed as a grand tribute to outback life that would transform a small rural town, but this Queensland museum will sit unfinished unless council can fill its funding shortfall.

title.children: Cost blowout halts grand plans for national outback museum

image.altText: a 10-year-old girl wearing earrings and makeup

props.synopsis: Ten-year old Sara Sharif loved singing and dreamed of being on The X Factor. Her death at the hands of her parents sent shock waves around the globe. Warning: This story contains graphic content that may be upsetting.

title.children: Parents found guilty of shocking murder of girl who dreamed of stardom
